definition: An organization that provides supportive healthcare services (e.g., laboratory, imaging, or rehabilitation) rather than primary medical care.
A facility where patients receive outpatient medical care, typically from physicians, nurse practitioners, or physician assistants.

Federally Qualified Health Center – A community-based healthcare organization that receives federal funding to provide comprehensive primary and preventive care services, regardless of patients’ ability to pay, often serving medically underserved areas or populations.
A healthcare practice where multiple providers (often physicians of the same or different specialties) work together to deliver care.
A licensed healthcare institution that provides inpatient, outpatient, emergency, and surgical services.
An organization focused on eye health services, such as optometry, ophthalmology, and vision correction.
A practice or facility that delivers oral health services, including preventive, diagnostic, and surgical dental care.
An organization providing mental health and substance use disorder services, such as counseling, therapy, and psychiatric care.
A licensed facility that dispenses prescription medications and may offer medication management or counseling.
A service provider that offers non-emergency medical transportation for patients to and from healthcare facilities.
An organization that supplies medical equipment and devices for repeated use, such as wheelchairs, oxygen equipment, or hospital beds.
